p: More than 120 components are characterized in the essential oil prepared from aerial parts of S. officinalis. The main components of the oil include borneol, camphor, caryophyllene, cineole, elemene, humulene, ledene, pinene, and thujone [ 9, 10, 11]. The sage oil has a direct effect on the nervous system [ 12]. Camphor, thujone, and terpene ketones are considered as the most toxic compounds in S. officinalis. These compounds may induce toxic effects. According to Veličković et al. [ 13], bornyl acetate, camphene, camphor, humulene, limonene, and thujone are the most comment phytochemicals in the leaves. However, it should be considered that, like other herbs, the chemical composition of S. officinalis varies depending on the environmental conditions such as climate, water availability, and altitude [ 14].
